Discrete State Markov Chain Equilibrium

Aug 2, 2018 • Troy Stribling

A Markov Chain is a sequence of states where transitions between states occur in time with the probability of a transition depending only on the previous state. Here the states will be assumed a discrete finite set and time a discrete unbounded set. If the set of states is given by {x1, x2,…, xN}\{x_1,\ x_2,\ldots,\ x_N\}{x1​, x2​,…, xN​} the probability that process will be in state xix_ixi​ at time ttt is denoted by P(Xt=xi)P(X_t=x_i)P(Xt​=xi​). Markov Chain equilibrium is defined by limt→∞P(Xt=xi) < ∞\lim_{t\to\infty}P(X_t=x_i)\ <\ \inftylimt→∞​P(Xt​=xi​) < ∞, that is, as time advances
P(Xt=xi)P(X_t=x_i)P(Xt​=xi​) becomes independent of time. Here a solution for this limit is discussed and illustrated with examples.

Model

The Markov Chain model is constructed from the set of states {x1, x2,…, xN}\{x_1,\ x_2,\ldots,\ x_N\}{x1​, x2​,…, xN​} in time. The process starts at time t=0t=0t=0 with state X0=xiX_0=x_iX0​=xi​. At the next step, t=1t=1t=1, the process will assume a state X1=xjX_1=x_jX1​=xj​ with probability P(X1=xj∣X0=xi)P(X_1=x_j|X_0=x_i)P(X1​=xj​∣X0​=xi​). At the next time step t=2t=2t=2 the process state will be X2=xkX_2=x_kX2​=xk​ with probability, P(X2=xk∣X0=xi,X1=xj)=P(X2=xk∣X1=xj), P(X_2=x_k|X_0=x_i, X_1=x_j)=P(X_2=x_k|X_1=x_j), P(X2​=xk​∣X0​=xi​,X1​=xj​)=P(X2​=xk​∣X1​=xj​), since the probability of state transition depends only upon the state at the previous time step. For an arbitrary time the transition to a state at the next time will occur with probability, P(Xt+1=xj∣Xt=xi)P(X_{t+1}=x_j|X_t=x_i)P(Xt+1​=xj​∣Xt​=xi​). Transition probabilities have the form of a matrix,

Pij=P(Xt+1=xj∣Xt=xi). P_{ij} = P(X_{t+1}=x_j|X_t=x_i). Pij​=P(Xt+1​=xj​∣Xt​=xi​).

PPP will be a square N×NN\times NN×N matrix where the size NNN is determined by the number of possible states. Each row represents the Markov Chain transition probability from that state at time ttt and the columns the values at t+1t+1t+1. It follows that, ∑j=1NPij=1Pij ≥ 0     (1). \begin{aligned} \sum_{j=1}^{N}P_{ij} &= 1\\ P_{ij}\ &\geq\ 0 \end{aligned} \ \ \ \ \ (1). j=1∑N​Pij​Pij​ ​=1≥ 0​     (1).

Equation (1)(1)(1) is the definition of a Stochastic Matrix.

The transition probability across two time steps can be obtained with use of the Law of Total Probability, P(Xt+2=xj∣Xt=xi)=∑k=1NP(Xt+2=xj∣Xt=xi,Xt+1=xk)P(Xt+1=xk∣Xt=xi)=∑k=1NP(Xt+2=xj∣Xt+1=xk)P(Xt+1=xk∣Xt=xi)=∑k=1NPkjPik=∑k=1NPikPkj=(P2)ij, \begin{aligned} P(X_{t+2}=x_j|X_t=x_i) &= \sum_{k=1}^{N} P(X_{t+2}=x_j | X_{t}=x_i, X_{t+1}=x_k)P(X_{t+1}=x_k | X_{t}=x_i) \\ &= \sum_{k=1}^{N} P(X_{t+2}=x_j | X_{t+1}=x_k)P(X_{t+1}=x_k | X_{t}=x_i) \\ &= \sum_{k=1}^{N} P_{kj}P_{ik} \\ &= \sum_{k=1}^{N} P_{ik}P_{kj} \\ &= {(P^2)}_{ij}, \end{aligned} P(Xt+2​=xj​∣Xt​=xi​)​=k=1∑N​P(Xt+2​=xj​∣Xt​=xi​,Xt+1​=xk​)P(Xt+1​=xk​∣Xt​=xi​)=k=1∑N​P(Xt+2​=xj​∣Xt+1​=xk​)P(Xt+1​=xk​∣Xt​=xi​)=k=1∑N​Pkj​Pik​=k=1∑N​Pik​Pkj​=(P2)ij​,​

where the last step follows from the definition of matrix multiplication. It is straight forward but tedious to use Mathematical Induction to extend the previous result to the case of an arbitrary time difference, τ\tauτ, P(Xt+τ=xj∣Xt=xi)=(Pτ)ij     (2). P(X_{t+\tau}=x_j|X_t=x_i) = {(P^{\tau})}_{ij}\ \ \ \ \ (2). P(Xt+τ​=xj​∣Xt​=xi​)=(Pτ)ij​     (2).

It should be noted that since (Pτ)ij{(P^{\tau})}_{ij}(Pτ)ij​ is a transition probability it must satisfy,

∑j=1N(Pτ)ij = 1(Pτ)ij ≥ 0     (3). \begin{aligned} \sum_{j=1}^{N} {(P^{\tau})}_{ij}\ &=\ 1 \\ {(P^{\tau})}_{ij}\ &\geq\ 0 \end{aligned} \ \ \ \ \ (3). j=1∑N​(Pτ)ij​ (Pτ)ij​ ​= 1≥ 0​     (3).

To determine the equilibrium solution of the probability distribution of the Markov Chain states, {x1, x2,…, xN}\{x_1,\ x_2,\ldots,\ x_N\}{x1​, x2​,…, xN​} its time variability must be determined. Begin by considering the distribution of states at t=0t=0t=0. This distribution can be written as a column vector, π=(π1π2⋮πN)=(P(X0=x1)P(X0=x2)⋮P(X0=xN)), \pi = \begin{pmatrix} \pi_1 \\ \pi_2 \\ \vdots \\ \pi_N \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} P(X_0=x_1) \\ P(X_0=x_2) \\ \vdots \\ P(X_0=x_N) \end{pmatrix}, π=⎝⎜⎜⎛​π1​π2​⋮πN​​⎠⎟⎟⎞​=⎝⎜⎜⎛​P(X0​=x1​)P(X0​=x2​)⋮P(X0​=xN​)​⎠⎟⎟⎞​,

where πi\pi_iπi​ must satisfy, ∑i=1Nπi = 1πi ≥ 0     (4). \begin{aligned} \sum_{i=1}^{N} \pi_i\ &=\ 1\\ \pi_i\ &\geq \ 0 \end{aligned} \ \ \ \ \ (4). i=1∑N​πi​ πi​ ​= 1≥ 0​     (4).

The distribution of states after the first step is given by, P(X1=xj)=∑i=1NP(X1=xj∣X0=xi)P(X0=xi)=∑i=1NPijπi=∑i=1NπiPij=(πTP)j, \begin{aligned} P(X_1=x_j) &= \sum_{i=1}^{N} P(X_1=x_j|X_0=x_i)P(X_0=x_i) \\ &= \sum_{i=1}^{N} P_{ij}\pi_{i} \\ &= \sum_{i=1}^{N} \pi_{i}P_{ij} \\ &= {(\pi^{T}P)}_{j}, \end{aligned} P(X1​=xj​)​=i=1∑N​P(X1​=xj​∣X0​=xi​)P(X0​=xi​)=i=1∑N​Pij​πi​=i=1∑N​πi​Pij​=(πTP)j​,​

where πT\pi^TπT is the transpose of π\piπ. Similarly, the distribution of states after the second step is, P(X2=xj)=∑i=1NP(X2=xj∣X1=xi)P(X1=xi)=∑i=1NPij(πTP)i=∑i=1NPij∑k=1NπkPki=∑k=1Nπk∑i=1NPijPki=∑k=1Nπk∑i=1NPkiPij=∑k=1Nπk(P2)kj=(πTP2)j, \begin{aligned} P(X_2=x_j) &= \sum_{i=1}^{N} P(X_2=x_j|X_1=x_i)P(X_1=x_i) \\ &= \sum_{i=1}^{N} P_{ij}{(\pi^{T}P)}_{i} \\ &= \sum_{i=1}^{N} P_{ij}\sum_{k=1}^{N} \pi_{k}P_{ki} \\ &= \sum_{k=1}^{N} \pi_{k} \sum_{i=1}^{N} P_{ij}P_{ki} \\ &= \sum_{k=1}^{N} \pi_{k} \sum_{i=1}^{N} P_{ki}P_{ij} \\ &= \sum_{k=1}^{N} \pi_{k} {(P^2)}_{kj} \\ &= {(\pi^{T}P^2)}_{j}, \end{aligned} P(X2​=xj​)​=i=1∑N​P(X2​=xj​∣X1​=xi​)P(X1​=xi​)=i=1∑N​Pij​(πTP)i​=i=1∑N​Pij​k=1∑N​πk​Pki​=k=1∑N​πk​i=1∑N​Pij​Pki​=k=1∑N​πk​i=1∑N​Pki​Pij​=k=1∑N​πk​(P2)kj​=(πTP2)j​,​

A pattern is clearly developing. Mathematical Induction can be used to prove the distribution of states at an arbitrary time ttt is given by, P(Xt=xj)=(πTPt)j P(X_t=x_j) = {(\pi^{T}P^t)}_{j} P(Xt​=xj​)=(πTPt)j​

or as a column vector,

πtT=πTPt     (5). \pi_{t}^{T} = \pi^{T}P^t\ \ \ \ \ (5). πtT​=πTPt     (5).

Where π\piπ and πtT\pi_t^TπtT​ are the transpose of the chain state distribution initially and after ttt steps respectively.

Equilibrium Distribution of States

The equilibrium distribution of states is defined by looking for a solution to equation (4) that is independent of time.

πT=πTPt     (6). \pi^{T} = \pi^{T}P^t\ \ \ \ \ (6). πT=πTPt     (6).

It is easy to show that, πET=πETP     (7), \pi_{E}^{T} = \pi_{E}^{T}P\ \ \ \ \ (7), πET​=πET​P     (7),

is a solution by substituting equation it into equation (6)(6)(6). πET=πETPt=(πETP)Pt−1=πETPt−1=πETPt−2⋮=πETP=πET \begin{aligned} \pi_{E}^{T} &= \pi_{E}^{T}P^t \\ &= (\pi_{E}^{T}P)P^{t-1} \\ &= \pi_{E}^{T}P^{t-1} \\ &= \pi_{E}^{T}P^{t-2} \\ &\vdots \\ &= \pi_{E}^{T}P \\ &= \pi_{E}^{T} \end{aligned} πET​​=πET​Pt=(πET​P)Pt−1=πET​Pt−1=πET​Pt−2⋮=πET​P=πET​​

Equilibrium Transition Matrix

The probability of transitioning between two states xix_ixi​ and xjx_jxj​ in ttt time steps was previously shown to be PtP^tPt with equation (3)(3)(3) defining the stochastic matrix conditions. The limit, limt→∞Pt     (8), \lim_{t\to\infty}P^{t}\ \ \ \ \ (8), t→∞lim​Pt     (8), of the can be evaluated using Diagonalizing. Matrix Diagonalization requires evaluation of the eigenvalues and eigenvectors, which are defined by the solutions to the equation, Pv=λv, Pv = \lambda v, Pv=λv, where vvv is the eigenvector and λ\lambdaλ eigenvalue. From equation (8)(8)(8) it follows that,
